Magnificent building. A grand cathedral with amazing decorated windows. The structure of the whole building is incredible. Views from the top are also a definite for those not scared of heights!!

One of the best in the world. This really should be put in the same category as Westminster Abbey or Notre Dame, or any of the world's major holy sites.GORGEOUS. The Mucha stained glass is amazing. It's free to get into, but you can pay to get to see more of the church or to get closer to certain items. It's not much.You can also easily spend 45 minutes just walking around the outside and admiring the detail. The Prague castle area is well worth the trip and a lovely walk from the metro exit nearby. Amazing views of Prague from up there. Don't miss it!

Stunning - a must see!. Entering the palace grounds, I looked to the left and was shocked and amazed to see how huge and magnificent the cathedral is. The inside is beautiful and definitely worth the tour. Take tram 22 from outside Mala Strana station to get to the palace area. Once there, you can buy combined tickets for the tours - I recommend a ticket that includes the cathedral and golden lane at a minimum.

The best cathedral ever. You must visit!. The art nouveau stained glass is just breathtaking! The terribly excessive but strangely fascinating silver tomb of St. Nepomuk is also worth seeing. A stunning cathedral that is defintely one of the best in the world,

One of the most beautiful Cathedrals in Europe.. I have visited many cathedrals in Europe, but this is one of the most beautiful. The stain glass was absolutely amazing, and on a sunny day, there is so much light inside. This was the highlight of the Prague Castle area.

Takes your breath away. A must see if you're in Prague. The most amazing cathedral I've seen in the world. It's best if you take a guided tour, but you'll be just as impressed by strolling through it alone.Fee is minimal (around 100 Czk, definetly worth it).

Stunningly Beautiful, with Stained Glass that will take your breath away. This cathedral is part of the Prague Castle complex. You may enter the cathedral and see a small portion at no cost, but to tour the majority of the cathedral you must buy a ticket. You may purchase aticket to visit only the cathedral, or you may purchase a ticket that allows you entry into other buildings in the castle complex. At any rate, buy the ticket, view all of the cathedral, and don't complain about having to pay to go into the cathedral. It is gorgeous and worth every penny, and it must cost a heckuva lot to operate the place so it is entirely reasonable to pay for entry. Getting off of my soapbox now...I have visited this cathedral several times and each time, the stained glass moves me to tears. It is so beautiful, much more colorful than I'm used to seeing in cathedrals. Mucha's Art Nouveau window stands out, as does the pink and red window across from it. Those are my favorites, but the other windows are beautiful as well. The cathedral has an impressive organ and I believe that brief organ concerts are held frequently. It's definitely worth looking into before heading to the cathedral, so you can arrive in time to attend if interested. The large pipes allow for amazingly deep, low, powerful notes that seem strong enough to start an eatrhquake. Not to be missed!!!

Gorgeous and Impressive Cathedral. I visited the exquisite gothic St. Vitus Cathedral with many baroque features - it is over-the-top in beauty and takes one's breath away. I walked all around the cathedral viewing and taking pictures of the many wonderful features, like the brightly colored beautiful stained glass windows with such detailed religious scenes, the pulpit, the spectacular tomb of St. Vitus with its ornate silver ornamentation - over a ton of silver has been used to create this outstanding tomb.St. Vitus Cathedral is part of the Prague Castle Complex and is a distinctive feature of Prague’s panorama and a must-see.

Beautiful sight, gives Notre Dame a run for its money!. Since we live in Prague, I have been here several times with visiting friends. It is a really remarkable place. You can enter the back area of the church without paying the entry fee. (Ticket takers stand along the left aisle by a barricade so that only paying guests can walk through the whole church.)Try to come on a sunny day and you'll take in one of the greatest sights Prague has to offer, with colored beams streaming down from the stained glass. Though you can't enter the church at night, many people visit then to take dramatic pictures of the lighted exterior.

Very impressive with great details. We were there in the peak season so there was a long queue before you get into and inside it was packed still the atmosphere is very impressive showing that the builders of those churches knew exactly how to inspire awe and the sense of something greater than humans into the believers. You can either simply go in and marvel at all the paintings, mosaiks, statues or take a guide who will explain a lot. On the other hand a good travel book will do the same. Try to find some time to really let your eye wander through the interior and not get bothered by the masses of tourists. Alone for the architecture and the artistry shown inside it is worth nearly one hour of visit. One important tip would be to go up the tower it is really the best sight you have in Prague. P.S. Charging seems to change, we came in free of charge but it was on a sunday

definitely worth the visit. The cathedral is a very impressive piece of gothic architecture. It will surely make you go "Wow!" the first time you see it. (OK, maybe not now that your expectations are too high :D )I visited Prague twice, and the first time entrance was free, but this year, it was charged. The guide told us that this changes occasionaly. You can go in, but only a small section. If you want to go further you have to go outside and purchase a ticket. There is no ticket for the cathedral alone, only combination tickets for entrance to various locations in the Prague castle, so i passed this time. Still, for those who haven't seen it I would recommend paying to enter, but with a guide. It holds so much history, and it's very interesting to hear about it.
Get the audio tour. There's lots to see here. Be sure to get the audio tour. You can spend hours listening to the tour and seeing the sights.

Best Mass ever attended. Attend mass on Sunday Morning and get to stick around for free on your own tour and take picstures of all the beauty offered in thsi cathedral. Mass was great, didn't matter that I don't speak Czech or Latin. If you been to one, you knwo whats going on. Great experience.

Highlight of the Prague Castle. My wife and I have visited many cathedrals in many different countries. Although not the grandest or the oldest, St. Vitus certainly stands for its stained glass, which include scenes done by different artists over the years. It is certainly the highlight of our visit to Prague Castle. Because we visited during the off-season in March, the gardens have not yet opened.The cathedral was only opened after Noon. Even so, the cathedral was packed with people. It was hard to move around without blocking someone taking photos. I can only imagine what it must be like during the peak season.I said earlier that St. Vitus is not the grandest cathedral. Notre Dame in Paris is certainly larger. But comparing one to another is pointless. Standing in St. Vitus, you will be blown away by its sheer magnitude. I think cathedrals were meant to be spectacles. Imagine what it must be like to attend mass here, hundreds of years ago, with a full choir and the organ playing. Long before today's rock concerts and Las Vegas shows.

St. Vitus Cathedral - pearl of Prague. Building of the main temple of kingdom St. Vitus Cathedral there has begun Charles IV in territory of the Prague Castle ( historical residence of the Czech kings, and nowadays president residences of the Czech Republic) the Prague Castle located on a height on the left coast of Vltava, are an architectural dominant of Prague. The stone fortification closes 12 century its constructions (palace and church constructions, gardens, fountains, bridges) in the isolated territory. The complex of the Prague Castle is opened for visiting daily (the ticket costs from 250 crones): from April, 1st till October, 31st from 5.00 till, during winter time 9.00 till 18.00; separate objects work: April-October from 9.00 till, November-March from 9.00 till 16.00. In the Prague Castle conduct smart gate from the Hradcany Square. At gate the guard of honor is exposed, changing of the guard is made each hour. The cathedral should become a place for crowning, a family crypt, a treasury. Cathedral building has begun in 1344 and in 1929, after 600 years of building, the St. Vitus Cathedral has been finished. Gothic St. Vitus Cathedral is fine and with наружи (simply captivates even from the big distance) and in a nutria (these Gothic arches, stained-glass windows). The mosaic "Last court" on the Southern facade is very beautiful.

Stunning! But don't purchase an informative tour.. There is no need, unless you don't know much about St. Vitus, to get a formal tour guide. A cathedral of this magnificence needs to be enjoyed in peace and quiet. Take your time, meander all the ins and outs, linger, Do not rush. Better to go later in the day, when the sunlight comes through the breathtaking stained glass windows. Especially one by the Czech artist Alphons Mucha. I was in awe.
A bit underwhelming really. A little underwhelming really, especially when compared to some of the other beautiful gems in Prague, such as St Nicholas Church.

The Highlight of the Castle complex. Worth paying the extra fee to be able to enter the main body of the Cathedral, for the views of the Rose window if nothing else. The tomb of John of Nepomuk is also spectacular but the stained glass was the highlight for me.

The Great South Tower Lookout Gallery = amazing but not for the claustrophobic. If you're up for climbing 287 steps in a tight, windy stairwell, the phenomenal view is worth it. To see St. Vitus Cathedral from up above is breathtaking. The city of Prague spreads out below the cathedral and it's gorgeous too. This was one of my most favorite picture taking opportunities. If you are claustrophobic, the Petrin Hill fake Eiffel Tower, is easier to climb and it has an elevator. I was able to do both lookout towers in the same afternoon and the comparison was amazing. I recommend climbing both, if you're able!

Absolutely beautiful. Not much to add here. One of the most spectacular Gothic churches in the world and should not be missed. I went in September when it wasn't peak season and there was no line up.As a side note, anyone who liked the St. Vitus should also check out the Church of St. Nicholas. It is about a 5 minute walk south of the castle complex but just as amazing in another style.

Impressive gothic architecture. St Vitus can be seen from all over Prague and is more impressive close up. The cathedral is free to enter. The kids enjoyed spotting the interesting gargoyles around the building. Inside, the stain glass windows are beautiful. The building is full of history.I visited during the day time and also very early in the morning. In the day time it is very busy, but if you get there early, you'll have the place to yourself.

Beautiful but crowded. I visited Prague last winter which is thier slow season and found the Cathedral to be very crowded i was on a tour and out tour guide had to shout over the other tours.Even though it is crowded is is well worth the visit it is one of the most beautiful cathedrals I have ever been in with plenty of interesting history.

Beautiful Cathedral - spoilt by bad attitude and inflexibility. St Vitus Cathedral, within the huge Prague castle complex is stunning - particularly its vibrant stained glass windows. The more famous of which are by Alfons Mucha "the Father of the global art nouveau movement".The castle complex opens at 05.00 so you can wander around in relative peace and quiet, the cathedral opens at 09.00 and is free to enter.I arrived at around 07.00, and as a keen photographer set up my tripod to take photos of the stunning carvings on the Cathedral side doors. There were very few people around, I was not blocking any access or road and there was ample space. Within a very few minutes a Policeman came and aggressively waved me to move - his point was I could take photos but not use the tripod. Bizarre, as 2 days earlier I had been there at the same time and used my tripod. However heavy rain started and I was forced to abandon - hence the return visit.I picked up my equipment and moved on. As I walked on I was surprised to see the main doors of the Cathedral wide open - by now it was about 07.20.I entered, it was very quiet, and set up my tripod to take the Mucha stained glass windows. Within a matter of minutes a Priest arrived, he spoke perfect English and rudely and aggressively told me to leave and that I could not use the tripod. Apparently the Cathedral was closed BUT why then the doors wide open.The attraction is stunning - colourful, historic and an interesting part of Czech history. However the attitude and inflexibility of these 2 people spoilt it completely. Whilst I respect and totally understand they must do their respective jobs, both approached me, a visitor to their country, with a poor people attitude and no flexibility. Had either said to me "take 5 minutes to finish and then go please" I would have understood.Don't let it put you off going, just beware if you are a keen photographer. If the Czech Republic, where the people are generally very welcoming, wants to attract visitors, the attitude of some officials will have to change and they will have to learn some rather better people skills.

Spectacular Cathedral, well worth a visit. You just wouldnt know that the Cathedral wasnt completed until the 1920's, although it was built over a period of 600 years. The interior is perhaps even more impressive with huge stained glass windows and much gilt in gold.The cathedral dominates the view from the old town side of the Vltava and is particularly striking at night - make sure you bring a tripod to get the best pics!In short, it has to be the most impressive part of the Hradcany (castle district)

Spectacular, but get there early!. We got to the cathedral really early, and there was already a queue. The interior was superb, and we spent a while walking round. Watch out for the pushy tour groups who shove you out of the way, stand your ground. We also went and viewed the exterior at night which was amazing. The pictures we got were spectacular.

Amazing. This is the main thing to see at Prague Castle and in Prague. It is free to enter and you can take pictures, just be aware the lines are very long (try to go very early). I would say this is the most beautiful building in all of Prague which says a lot and the most important thing to do in the city. The architecture and the craftsmanship is awe imspiring to say the least and in all my travels all over the world it is probably in the top three of most stunning buildings I have seen. It will take you atleast an hour to see and probably longer if it is busy as you really want to take your time to check it out. I did not rent the audio guide but I would recommend doing so as the history of the Cathedral would be incredible to hear.

Beware of the Waiting Line. This august edifice is the most impressive building inside the whole Prague castle. However, there is almost always a big queue at the entrance (literally up to 20-30 metres at times), so I recommend to go there as early as possible and visit this monument first in the whole castle to savor its magnitude...

Well worth visiting. One of the best bits of Prague Castle for me. The interior is spectacular and it's free to enter. The stained glass windows are particularly good bu the most unusual feature is the 1600Kg sold silver tomb of St John of Nepomuk - haven't seen anything as spectacular outside of St Peters.

Must see when in Prague. This Cathedral impressed as a lot. It takes your breath away. It's located into the city's castle, Hradcany. The entry is free. Usually, there is a long queue but when we visited (november) there were only a few people outside. Anyway, if you rent an audio guide, you skip the line and go directly in. We had one but it wasn't worthy in my opinion. I wouldn't buy one again. So, my advice: go visit the Saint Vitus Cathedral :)
You've got to see this. A breathtaking cathedral that creates various emotions to the visitor

Very Impressive. This should be a must for any visitor to Prague. It is gothic and gorgeous. The windows and light are beautiful inside. we were fortunate to visit on a lovely suny afternoon and it was quite beautiful.The entry is free - but do watch the time you visit as when we first went it had closed. i think the cathedral closes at 4.00pm. We liked the icey gargoyles very much too.
Stunning - the only thing worth seeing at Prague Castle. Very beautiful. Entry is free. It was not very crowded at all when we visted in early January. Very much worth a visit!

gorgeous. This church is part of the standard castle tour and quite beautiful. It is too bad the windows are all darkened with what I believe is soot, but outside of that, the church is quite a site. If you get a chance to inside you should definitely take it. The history behind the church is also interesting, telling in part why the whole thing is not built in the gothic style.

Breathtaking. But still very crowded, even in late September. Lots of schoolkids. Still, the cathedral itself is a showstopper, though the tower was closed when we went. Be sure to check out the portico on the side of the church with the gold sculptures of the signs of the zodiac on the gate.

Very nice cathedral. A very nice, but not great cathedral. It was nice that they do not charge for admission, but the result is that it is very busy and there was a long line the day we visited. Certainly worth a visit, but not memorable.
Worth a Visit - Quite Beautiful. The biggest and probably the most important Church in this country. A gothic beauty. Anyone visiting Prague should put this on their must see list.

Another Gothic cathedral--quite undestinguished. One can become jaded (as I have) by seeing too many Gothic cathedrals---this one is not worth standing in line for in my opinion. The stained glass is always beautiful but not close in quality to say the cathedral in Reims, France and many others.Except for the views, the tour of St. Vitus and the Prague "castle" were not in my top ten.

Best collection of stained glass windows I've ever seen. Several other reviewers have done a good job of capturing the beauty of St. Vitus. All I will add is that I've never seen so many gorgeous stained glass windows in one location. The building is worth the visit for the windows alone. I've attached several photos (including one by 20th century artist Alphonse Mucha), but it is impossible to capture the beauty of the windows with a hand-held camera.

Beautiful Cathedral. St. Vitus Cathedral, a gorgeous gothic structure that overlooks all of Prague, is well worth a visit. It is located on the Prague Castle grounds and you and both getting to it (by walking through the grounds) and going inside is free. Within, you will find some gorgeous stained glass windows, including one done by the famous Czech Art Nouveau painter Alfons Mucha. This gorgeous window, which stands out noticeably in style from the rest, is worth the visit alone. Beyond that, you will find many attractive chapels, as well as a massive silver tomb dedicated to St. John of Nepomuk. Overall, it's a beautiful cathedral inside and out, and not to be missed.

Beautiful Cathedral!!. St. Vitus's Cathedral was the highlight of my trip to Prague and the most beautiful cathedral I've ever been in (surpassing Notre Dame as my previous favorite)! I cannot stress how gorgeous it is inside; the pictures don't come close to doing it justice.Because St. Vitus's is so beautiful, there are a lot of people wanting to visit, and when we were there the line to get in the cathedral snaked all the way along the side and to the back. I can only imagine that it is worse in the summer / peak travel season, but there is one way you can skip the line: rent an audio guide! With your audio guide you get immediate entrance to the cathedral through the exit; this easily saved us over an hour of waiting time (in very cold weather), and it also provides you with an explanation about each relic, stained glass window, and altar you see. Double-check when renting the audio guide that this policy is still in place, but if it is - it is worth the money to save you the time waiting! Plan to spend 45 mintues to an hour in the cathedral - it is huge, with lots of people and lots to see.

A beautiful cathedral. This cathedral is beautiful inside. And while you do have to wait inline and outside to be let in, this provides that it is not packed like other cathedrals. So you can enjoy yourself and the space without being bumped and shoved. The ability to go up the tower is pretty awesome. There are some great views. However, the climb up leaves something to be desired. 287 spiral stairs with 287 people going up and down at the same time.

St. Vitus: An Incredible European Cathedral. Located within the confines of the immense Prague Castle, St. Vitus is the dominant feature of Prague, the spiritual symbol of the Church, and a major, and heavily visited, stop in any trip.I visited St. Vitus during my recent trip to Prague; several things to update since the previous reviews: 1. The cathedral is no longer included in the general admission to Prague Castle having changed "ownership" (if this is the appropriate term). While you may look at the exquisite interior from the front for no fee - and stand packed amid a gaggle of fellow tourists - I recommend paying the extra 100 crowns and explore this marvelous building, especially the aforementioned stained glass windows. You can also visit the crypt - if this is your thing.2. I was not required to pay a fee to photograph the interior, which come out very well in an "Auto" setting. (Will submit some photos upon preparation.) A must see!

Take a Guide Book or Tour. This Cathedral was much like any other (but then i have had the luxury of viewing some stunning European Cathedrals). So if you like them you will enjoy this. It is really the only part of the Hrad complex worth seeing (apart from Golden Lane)!The stained glass is fabulous, for those who like that kind of thing. the enourmous silver monument is also something to behold. the tower is an intersting activity - you cram yourself into a small winding staircase with people going in both directions, its really questionable on health and safety grounds! there are over 300 steps, but is perfectly achievable for someone of average fitness, anyone bothered by tight spaces should not try it though. Don't take loads of bags either - leave them with grandma at the bottom! The views are very good, but not really worth the climb - there are better view points in the city. Its one to say you have done rather than do it because its great!There are few labels or signs for the different aspects of the cathedral and you won't know what you are looking at if you are not on a tour or are without a guide book.

Stunning. I would strongly suggest paying extra for the photography privilege. There is enough light inside for flash-less shots and the stained glass windows are stunning, particularly the Mucha.The tower ascent is brutal but also recommended. The view is incredible. A word of warning, however, to those visitors from countries in which (how do I put this delicately?) personal hygiene is a priority: you will be climbing nearly 300 steps in a small space with little ventilation and lots of people...people for whom personal hygiene is not a priority. Go on a hot afternoon and take your chances. It's a tricky climb in some places when crowded. Not advised for people with any physical disabilities whatsoever. I am fit and I was sore the next day.
